results.adx_keywords: Bicycles and Bicycling;Falls;United States Politics and Government;Biden, Joseph R Jr;Rehoboth Beach (Del)
results.title: Biden Takes Tumble During Bike Ride in Delaware
results.abstract: The president did not need medical attention after he fell off his bike at a state park near his vacation home in Rehoboth Beach, according to the White House.

media.caption: President Biden after falling off his bike at Cape Henlopen State Park in Delaware. He and the first lady were spending the weekend at their vacation home in Rehoboth Beach.
media.copyright: Sarah Silbiger for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Storming of the US Capitol (Jan, 2021);Presidential Election of 2020;United States Politics and Government;Voter Fraud (Election Fraud);Rumors and Misinformation;Treason and Sedition;Ethics and Official Misconduct;Trump, Donald J;House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack;Justice Department
results.byline: By Michael S. Schmidt and Maggie Haberman
results.title: Despite Growing Evidence, a Prosecution of Trump Would Face Challenges
results.abstract: As House hearings highlighted testimony that could create more pressure to pursue a criminal case, the former president tried out a defense that strained credulity.
org_facet: House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack

media.caption: Former President Donald J. Trump at a rally in Casper, Wyo., last month. If the Justice Department brings a case against him, the prosecution could hinge on the government’s ability to establish his intent.
media.copyright: Natalie Behring for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Holidays and Special Occasions;Juneteenth;States (US);Law and Legislation;Black People;Budgets and Budgeting
results.title: Juneteenth Is a Federal Holiday, but in Most States It’s Still Not a Day Off
results.abstract: One year after President Biden made Juneteenth a federal holiday, 26 states have not authorized the funding that would allow for state employees to take the day off.

media.caption: Juneteenth celebrations in Brooklyn. New York is one of the states that gave state employees paid time off to commemorate the day last year.
media.copyright: Laylah Amatullah Barrayn for The New York Times

results.title: Spelling Bee Forum
results.abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.

results.title: Republican Drive to Tilt Courts Against Climate Action Reaches a Crucial Moment
results.abstract: A Supreme Court environmental case being decided this month is the product of a coordinated, multiyear strategy by Republican attorneys general and conservative allies.

media.caption: Republican attorneys want to hem in what they call the administrative state, the E.P.A. and other federal agencies that set rules and regulations that affect the American economy.
media.copyright: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Extraterrestrial Life;Telescopes and Observatories;Space and Astronomy;SETI Institute;China
results.title: A Chinese Telescope Did Not Find an Alien Signal. The Search Continues.
results.abstract: China’s astronomers have been initiated into the search for extraterrestrial intelligence with the kind of false alarm that others in the field have experienced for decades.

media.caption: An aerial view of the FAST telescope in China’s Guizhou province. Astronomers there recently detected a signal that was mistaken for extraterrestrial intelligence.
media.copyright: National Astronomical Observatories of the Chinese Academy of Sciences

results.title: Why a Rhodes Scholar’s Ambition Led Her to a Job at Starbucks
results.abstract: Jaz Brisack became a barista for the same reasons that talented young people have long chosen their career paths: a mix of idealism and ambition.
org_facet: American Federation of Labor-Congress of Industrial Organizations

media.caption: Jaz Brisack, a Rhodes scholar, on her way to work in February at a Starbucks in Buffalo, where she helped unionize co-workers.

results.title: Two Cast Members of ‘The Chosen One’ on Netflix Killed in Accident
results.abstract: The accident happened in transit to a local airport in Baja California Sur in Mexico. Six other cast and crew members were injured, Netflix confirmed.

media.caption: The Netflix show “The Chosen One” started shooting in Mexico in April.
media.copyright: Frederic J. Brown/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

results.byline: By Azi Paybarah and David Montgomery
results.title: Texas Republicans Approve Far-Right Platform Declaring Biden’s Election Illegitimate
results.abstract: The platform, which was voted on at the Republican state party convention in Houston, was the latest sign of Texas conservatives moving further to the right.

media.caption: A resolution adopting the false claim that former President Donald J. Trump was the victim of a stolen election in 2020 was passed by Republican state-party delegates in Texas.
media.copyright: Leah Millis/Reuters

results.title: Mark Shields, TV Pundit Known for His Sharp Wit, Dies at 85
results.abstract: A former campaign strategist, he became a fixture in American political journalism and punditry and was seen on “PBS NewsHour” for 33 years.

media.caption: The political commentator Mark Shields at his home in Chevy Chase, Md., in 2020. Politics had loomed large for him since he was a boy.
media.copyright: Valerie Plesch for The New York Times

results.title: Sure, Just Have the Baby
results.abstract: There are good reasons American women overwhelmingly choose having an abortion over giving up a child for adoption.

results.byline: By Jeanna Smialek and Ben Casselman
results.title: This Is Going to Hurt
results.abstract: Inflation is expected to remain high later this year even as the economy slows and layoffs rise. Already, signs of financial stress are surfacing.

results.byline: By Mike McIntire, Glenn Thrush and Eric Lipton
results.title: Gun Sellers’ Message to Americans: Man Up
results.abstract: The number of firearms in the U.S. is outpacing the country’s population, as an emboldened gun industry and its allies target buyers with rhetoric of fear, machismo and defiance.

media.caption: A man raffled off a golden AK-47 at the N.R.A. convention last month in Houston.
media.copyright: Mark Abramson for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Palaces and Castles;Historic Buildings and Sites;Restoration and Renovation;Home Repairs and Improvements;Content Type: Personal Profile;Books and Literature;DePree, Hopwood;Middleton (England)
results.title: ‘Downton Shabby’: A Commoner Takes on an English Castle
results.abstract: A Los Angeles actor and producer moved across the pond to restore his crumbling ancestral home. But fixing up a 50,000-square-foot manor isn’t easy.

media.caption: “I first came to see the hall out of curiosity,” said Hopwood DePree, whose initial tour of his ancestral home, in 2013, included the morning room. He decided to stick around to bring the centuries-old property back to its early splendor.
media.copyright: Dave Brogan

results.title: Gustavo Petro wins the Colombian election, becoming the country’s first leftist president.
results.abstract: The victory by the former rebel and longtime senator sets the third-largest nation in Latin America on a new path.

media.caption: Gustavo Petro and Francia Márquez celebrating after winning the elections on Sunday in Bogotá, Colombia.
media.copyright: Federico Rios for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Gun Control;Uvalde, Tex, Shooting (May 24, 2022);Law and Legislation;Firearms;Federal Bureau of Investigation;New Yorkers Against Gun Violence;Giffords (Advocacy Group)
results.byline: By Glenn Thrush and Serge F. Kovaleski
results.title: Loopholes and Missing Data: The Gaps in the Gun Background Check System
results.abstract: The massive system already has major loopholes advocated by gun manufacturers to maintain easier access to firearms. The Senate’s proposed gun reform measures could fall victim to those same limitations.

media.caption: Shopping at Tobacco Valley Gun in East Windsor, Conn. The National Instant Background Check System contains built-in limitations, some of which exist because the gun lobby pushed to speed up gun sales.
media.copyright: Christopher Capozziello for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Capitol Building (Washington, DC);Comedy and Humor;Television;CBS Corporation;United States Capitol Police
results.byline: By Vimal Patel and Mike Ives
results.title: ‘Late Show’ Production Team Arrested at U.S. Capitol While Filming Television Stunt
results.abstract: The production team members had been recording interviews at a Capitol building for a comedy segment on “The Late Show With Stephen Colbert.” They were charged with unlawful entry.

media.caption: The actor and comedian Robert Smigel performs as Triumph the Insult Comic Dog at the Capitol on Thursday, before members of the “Late Show With Stephen Colbert” were arrested as part of an apparent stunt there.
media.copyright: Chip Somodevilla/Getty Images

results.adx_keywords: Black People;Slavery (Historical);Emancipation Proclamation (1863);United States Politics and Government;Juneteenth;Trump, Donald J;Galveston (Tex);Tulsa (Okla)
results.title: Juneteenth: The History of a Holiday
results.abstract: On June 19, 1865, enslaved African Americans in Texas were told they were free. A century and a half later, people across the U.S. continue to celebrate the day, which is now a federal holiday.

media.caption: Spectators watch a Juneteenth parade in 2021 in Galveston, Texas, where the holiday got its start in the latter half of the 19th century.
media.copyright: Callaghan O'Hare/Reuters
